security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing TimescaleDB database documentation in markdown format. No executable code, scripts, binaries, or network capabilities detected. The skill only provides informational responses about TimescaleDB features and usage.

content.value_statement: TimescaleDB transforms PostgreSQL into a powerful time-series database. This skill provides comprehensive guidance on hypertables, continuous aggregates, compression, and real-time analytics to help you build scalable monitoring, IoT, and financial applications.
actual_capabilities: Create and manage hypertables for time-series data partitioning
Implement continuous aggregates for automated data summarization
Configure compression policies to reduce storage costs
Write optimized time-series queries using hyperfunctions
Set up data retention and tiering policies
Migrate from PostgreSQL or other databases to TimescaleDB
limitations: Requires PostgreSQL 12 or later with TimescaleDB extension installed
Best performance with proper chunk interval configuration
Continuous aggregates require time-based bucket definitions
Some advanced features require TimescaleDB 2.13 or newer

faq.question: What PostgreSQL versions support TimescaleDB?
faq.answer: TimescaleDB supports PostgreSQL 12 through 17. Version compatibility varies - TimescaleDB 2.22+ requires PostgreSQL 15+.

faq.question: How does compression affect query performance?
faq.answer: Compressed data in the columnstore provides faster analytics by reducing I/O. Recent data remains uncompressed for fast inserts and point queries.

faq.question: Can I use TimescaleDB with my existing PostgreSQL applications?
faq.answer: Yes, TimescaleDB is a PostgreSQL extension. Existing applications connect via standard PostgreSQL protocols without code changes.

faq.question: How much storage space does compression save?
faq.answer: TimescaleDB compression typically reduces storage by 90% or more for time-series data by storing columnar data in array format.

faq.question: Why are my continuous aggregate queries slow?
faq.answer: Check that your continuous aggregate has a refresh policy configured. Real-time aggregates may need time to materialize the initial data.

faq.question: How does TimescaleDB compare to InfluxDB or other time-series databases?
faq.answer: TimescaleDB combines PostgreSQL compatibility with time-series optimizations. It offers SQL querying, joins with relational data, and mature tooling.
